title-group.article-title: Lattice Boltzmann simulation of magneto-hydrodynamic double-diffusive natural convection in an enclosure with internal heat and solute source using nanofluids

institution-wrap.institution: Iran University of Science and Technology (IUST)

abstract.title: Abstract

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Studying and modeling heat transfer and fluid flow in cavities is highly favorable due to the numerous applications in both industrial and academic fields, such as electronic cooling, heat exchangers, solar collector-receivers, solidification processes, energy storage systems, and many other devices that are run by thermal buoyancy, in which the major heat transfer mechanism is considered to be natural convection. Those applications were reviewed by Ostrach [1]. The problem with conventional convective systems is the low thermal conductivity of the working fluids [2]. An advanced technique to improve heat transfer efficiency is by using dispersed solid nanoparticles (smaller than 100 nm) in a working fluid which is known as nanofluid [3]. The implementation of this technique has been reported extensively over the past years to enhance heat transfer rate in industrial applications such as double pipe heat exchangers and channels, and the results have shown success in achieving this goal [4, 5].

Applying nanoparticles in the base fluid contributes to the heat and mass transfer enhancement in two ways, the one contribution is due to the Brownian movement of nanoparticles which transports heat (diffusion of nanoparticles), and the other contribution is due to an improvement in fluid thermal features [6]. Wong and Castillo [7] analyzed the impact of nanofluids in heat transfer through various experimental models, and theories regarding the heat transfer mechanism. Kolsi et al. [8] considered a cubical enclosure which contains water-Al2O3 nanofluids, and investigated the impact of various parameters such as Rayleigh number and solid volume portion on its heat transfer. A control volume finite element method has been implemented for this work. The results of this work indicate that the increase in solid particles percentage and Rayleigh number can result in an enlargement of Nusselt number. Jou and Tzeng [9] studied free convection of a nanofluid in a rectangular cavity with the implementation of a stream function-vorticity formulation and by using a finite difference method. Heat transfer characteristics and related fluid flow features inside enclosures as a function of affecting parameters of the system such as Rayleigh number, the aspect ratio of the considered enclosure, and the volume fraction of applied nanoparticles were presented and discussed. Their results showed that by increasing volume fraction of nanoparticles the average heat transfer coefficient increases. Ho, et al. [10] investigated effects of adding Al2O3 nanoparticles on viscosity and thermal conductivity of working fluid in a buoyant driven enclosure. The major effects of employing different models for viscosity and thermal conductivity on fluid flow inside the cavity and related thermal performance were extracted and reported.

Kumar et al. [11] numerically investigated fluid flow and thermal field in Cu-water nanofluid considering single-phase thermal dispersion and semi-explicit finite volume solver in a collocated grid. The influence of nanoparticles on the density and viscosity of fluid were investigated, and it was concluded that increasing the volume fraction of the suspended nanoparticle results in an increment in the surface area and the heat transfer capacity of the base fluid, which leads to a higher Nusselt number on the walls.

Chen et al. [12] implemented LBM to study free and mixed convection of Al2O3 containing nanofluid. The designed geometry in their study was a square enclosure. Numerical results were extracted to investigate the effects of buoyancy, natural convective influence relative to forced convective effects, and the convective heat transfer effects of nanofluids. As a result of this work, it was found that in natural convection, the temperature and flow patterns are highly influenced by Rayleigh number as in mixed convection Reynolds number finds the dominating role. Furthermore, the convective heat transfer effect is expanded as Richardson number increases, and the structure of the flow field changes.

Corcione, et al. [13] studied nanofluid buoyancy-driven convection in a square enclosure by utilizing a two-phase mixture model. The finite volume method was adopted to discretize the governing equations and coupled equations and to solve them numerically by the SIMPLE-C algorithm. As a result, to conclude the influence of the slip motion occurring between solid and fluid phases, the amount of heat transferred across the enclosure by the nanofluid is significantly higher than the transferred amount from the pure fluid. Moreover, the heat transfer within the enclosure was found as a rising function of nanofluid concentration up to an optimized particle concentration. It was also found that heat transfer within the cavity is increased by increasing the nanofluid average temperature and the cavity width, and is decreasing by an increment in the nanoparticle size. The above literature review deals with fluid motion only caused by a temperature gradient. However, the fluid motion may be induced due to gradients of other scalar quantities. The solute gradients can lead to motion in the absence or presence of temperature field, and can also play a crucial role in this process which this system is known as the double-diffusive convection. Nanoparticles can influence the fluid flow pattern and heat and mass transfer characteristics. The double-diffusive phenomenon can exist everywhere in nature and also in industries. In nature, it often happens in oceans, lakes, solar ponds, shallow coastal waters, and the atmosphere as well as industrial examples including chemical processes, crystal growth, energy storage, freezing, and food processing [14].

Simulation of combined double-diffusive convection and volumetric radiation in a square cavity was conducted by Moufekkir et al. [4].The proposed numerical method relay on a coupling between the hybrid lattice Boltzmann, the finite difference method, and the discrete ordinates method.

Moufekkir et al. [15] studied double-diffusive convection and volumetric radiation in an ordinated and differentially heated square enclosure employing multiple relaxation time lattice Boltzmann (MRT-LB) and finite difference method (FDM). The reported data include the influence of Rayleigh number, buoyancy number, the optical thickness, and the tilted angle on the flow fields and the heat and mass transfer. Kefayati [16] studied double-diffusive natural convection of Bingham fluid in a cavity with different orientations. The finite-difference lattice Boltzmann method (FDLBM) was adopted, and the effect of Soret and Dufour were analyzed in the cavity in different simulation conditions for various values of Rayleigh number, Bingham number, Lewis number, Dufour parameter, Soret parameter, Eckert number, inclined angle, and the Buoyancy ratio. Sheng Chen et al. [17] studied laminar and turbulence regimes of double-diffusion natural convection in a square cavity containing nanofluid by using LBM. In addition, the influence of the ratio of buoyancy forces on the improvement of double-diffusive convection of nanofluid was presented and discussed. The results imply the difference caused by adding nanoparticles into the base fluid for laminar and turbulence regimes.

Investigation on the fluid flow and thermal performance in the presence of a magnetic field is technically important due to the possibility to induce and control the fluid circulation and heat and mass transfer phenomenon by utilizing an external magnetic field, which can contribute to a vast range of applications including magnetically controlled thermosiphons for technological purposes, geothermal reservoirs, thermal insulation, oil tanks, improvement in heat transfer for cooling of high-power electric transformers, magnetically controlled heat transfer in energy conversion systems and variety of industrial applications.

Hussein et al. [18] applied a finite difference method to model laminar steady MHD natural convection in a tiled T-shaped enclosure filled with different types of nanofluids. The results showed that the mean Nusselt number rises with an increment of Rayleigh number, inclination angle, aspect ratio, heat source location, and volume fraction of nanoparticles, while, it decreases when the Hartmann number and heat source length increase.

Rudraiah et al. [19] numerically studied the impact of a magnetic field on free convection of an electrically conducting fluid in a rectangular enclosure. The results indicated an enhancement in the value of the magnetic field suppressing fluid flow and as a result that the average Nusselt number was decreased, in a strong magnetic field, the value of Nusselt number approaches to a unit value. Magneto-hydrodynamic natural convection in an open enclosure was analyzed by Hussein et al. [20]. This work considers the nanofluid as water–Cu, and numerous elements such as the effective conductivity, the impact of Hartmann number, nanofluid solid volume fraction, etc. are calculated numerically using LBM, and in the presence of a magnetic field. Kahveci et al. [21] investigated the natural convection flow and heat transfer fields in a laterally heated enclosure with an eccentric partition. It was concluded that the magnetic field that was anticipated in the x-direction is more effective in damping convective flow than the y-direction magnetic field, and it showed an average reduction rate of heat transfer with an increase in the distance of the partition from the hot wall. Ece and Buyuk [22] conducted a parametric study regarding the laminar MHD free convection in a rectangular enclosure with heated and cooled adjacent walls. The damping effect of the magnetic field on fluid flow patterns and heat transfer rate was observed. The different aspect ratios of the enclosure and orientation of geometry and magnitude of exerted magnetic field were also investigated and a significant effect of the fluid flow and temperature fields were observed.

The finite-difference lattice Boltzmann method was adopted to model heat transfer and entropy generation of laminar natural convection of non-Newtonian nanofluids in a square cavity in the presence of horizontal magnetic source by Kefayati [23]. Results indicate that the heat transfer drops by an increase in Hartmann number, and also affects the power-law index and nanoparticles influence on heat transfer.

Sheikholeslami and Ellahi [24] adopted the lattice Boltzmann method to study MHD hydrothermal treatment in a cubic cavity heated from the bottom of the cube. The results were obtained by considering different values of Hartmann number, nanoparticle volume fraction, and Rayleigh number. Streamlines, isotherms, and isokinetic energy, as well as the Nusselt number, were presented and discussed. It can be inferred that heat transfer caused by fluid flow decreased by applying a magnetic field as a result of an exerted force in the opposite direction of fluid flow. In addition, the Nusselt number was shown to be an increasing function of Rayleigh number and nanofluid volume fraction and a decreasing function of the Hartmann number.

Teamah et al. [25] proposed a numerical simulation to study the impact of a magnetic field on double-diffusive natural convection in a trapezoidal enclosure. A finite volume method was applied to solve the governing equations. The results were shown for different values of Grashof number, the inclination angle of the wall of the cavity, Hartmann number, and buoyancy ratio. The streamlines, isotherms, and iso-concentrations and results for both the local and average Nusselt and Sherwood numbers were presented and justified. It can be concluded that heat and mass transfer rates decrease with inclination angle increment and decrease with Hartmann number increment.

Farooq et al. [26] investigated the effect of magneto-hydrodynamic on squeezing the flow of nanoparticles in the middle of two restricted boundaries. In this work, fundamental explanations have been practiced for convectively heated Maxwell nanofluid by using Buongiorno’s model in the mathematical development of the assumed flow problem. The result of this work shows that the velocity profile illustrates cross flow features for increasing the values of the material parameter. Also, for governing values of Biot number, the convective impact is dominant on the plate surface and helps the temperature and nanoparticle concentration increase drastically close to the surface. The effect of using nanofluids in heat and mass transfer besides the controlling capability of the external magnetic field on nanofluids introduced a new field in fluid Mechanics and heat and mass transfer called magnetic nano-fluids (MNF) [27].

A study on free convection of magnetic nanofluid considering MFD viscosity was conducted by Sheikholeslami et al. [28] in enclosure geometry. The employed numerical method reported CVFEM, and the fluid is treated as a single phase. A parametric study was conducted to investigate the effect of non-dimensional numbers including viscosity parameter, Hartmann number, and Rayleigh number on the hydrothermal behavior of the fluid.

The detailed analysis of the literature presented above demonstrates a lack of deep understanding of a general study about the effect of internally positioned heat and solute source in an enclosure with permeable walls. The present study can be a good representative for modeling contaminant and heat removal systems, drug and food treatment processes and absorption and adsorption in chemical and petrochemical processing in the absence of magnetic field but by combining via magnetic field effect this problem is classified as a new field in fluid Mechanics and heat and mass transfer called magnetic nano-fluids (MNF).
The main application of MNF is in heat exchanger industries, geothermal energy, microelectronics, MEMS, and anywhere which magnetic fields influence fluid flow.

The parametric study is performed for multifarious values of the dimensionless governing parameters, such as Rayleigh, Lewis and Hartmann number, nanoparticles volume fraction, average Nusselt and Sherwood number, and different types of nanoparticles.

A detailed review has been presented in this section to give a better understanding of the recent works, and the importance of the present study. The following section (Sect. 2), includes problem description, the classical governing equations, lattice Boltzmann numerical method formulation, classical and lattice Boltzmann boundary conditions definitions, and finally the required correlation to approximate and calculate nanofluid thermos-physical properties. The next section (Sect. 3) is devoted to illustrate the iterative numerical method algorithm, grid independency study, and validating the generated code with regards to previous studies. The results are presented and discussed in Sect. 4, which is divided into four subsections for investigation each parameter individually. Finally, Sect. 5 presents a conclusion of the study, in which the research findings are concisely discussed.

sec.title: Classical mathematical modeling
sec.p: A uniform magnetic field of magnitude B is available in the horizontal direction. The fluid in the enclosure is a water-based nanofluid containing different types of solid particles such as Al2O3, Cu, and Ag. The nanofluid is considered Newtonian, single-phase fluid, incompressible, and laminar.
The imposed magnetic field in the horizontal direction causes a magnetic force influencing the flow domain in the vertical direction.

sec.title: Lattice Boltzmann method implementation
sec.p: Lattice Boltzmann method is utilized to simulate different hydrodynamics systems [36, 37]. The reason for the popularity of LBM over conventional CFD methods is the local dynamic and special nature of this method that allows users to easily parallel the computation and simple adoption of the method. The method uses the probability of detecting fluid particles in a certain range of velocity at a certain range of locations instead of tagging each particle as in the computationally-intensive molecular dynamics simulation approach. LBM simulates fluid particles colliding and moving on a uniform square grid to catch macroscopic fluid quantities including velocity, pressure, temperature, and concentration.

The implemented LBM in the present study uses three distribution functions f, g, and h for flow part, temperature and concentration fields, respectively. For the implementation of the LBM method, the fluid domain discretizes to form a uniform Cartesian cell and Each cell holds a fixed number of distribution functions, which represents the number of fluid particles moving in the discrete directions. The general form of the lattice Boltzmann equation is presented below [38, 39]:

sec.title: Modeling suspended nanoparticles in the main fluid
Algorithm, validation and grid independency
Results and discussion
sec.p: As it was mentioned at the beginning of the article in the introduction section, there are a large number of heat transfer systems based on the concept of free movement and fluid motion based on temperature gradient [1]. Which by applying nanofluids, the problems of low heat transfer coefficient of conventional fluids were largely solved [3]. However, it should be noted that temperature gradient is not the only parameter that induces motion, or alters fluid motion, and changes in heat and mass transfer patterns, but also other influential parameters, including concentration gradient, and applying a magnetic field can be mentioned [14, 17, 19, 27].In this article, it has been tried to deal with the interaction of temperature gradient, the concentration, size of the magnetic field, and the type of nanofluid. Fluid geometry is a heat and concentration square shaped source that is located in the middle of a cavity filled with nanofluids. This geometry is a useful geometry for many industries. The specific geometry of this study along with the implementation of lattice Boltzmann method as a newer and more modern numerical modeling method compared to conventional methods such as volume control, finite difference or the combination of such method [34, 55, 56], are the main distinguishing features of this article from previous studies. In the following, the effect of each parameter on a different subsection is examined, and each subsection can be a model for the process of various industries such as steelmaking, geothermal, heat exchangers, solidification processes, and so on. Therefore:

sec.title: Effect of different type of nanoparticles
sec.p: The presence of nanoparticles in water improves both the effective thermal conductivity and diffusion effects which leads to an increase in the intensity of fluid flow. Most articles examine the effect of different parameters on one type of nanofluid. However, only a few works have studied several quantities of various nanofluids. In the present research, three different types of nanoparticles are worked on. The innovation of this part of the study is the use of the Patel conductivity calculation model [47] for nanoparticles, which compared to the conventional models [57–59], takes the Brownian motion effect of particles, and the increase in heat transfer due to the increase in surface area (Increase in the specific surface area as well as Brownian motion) into account using a micro-convection model, which has a wider range of performance and higher accuracy than older models.

sec.title: Effect of Rayleigh number
sec.p: Rayleigh number is a dimensionless number in fluid mechanics that is closely related to the heat transfer regime of the floating current or free movement. This parameter has been extensively studied in previous studies. Based on the problem conditions and the type of geometry, the change in heat transfer mechanism from conduction to convection occurs in a specific Rayleigh number for this work and cannot be extracted from previous studies [60, 61].

Furthermore, an increment of Rayleigh number causes enhanced convective heat transfer, so isotherms and isoconcentration lines change completely and thermal and solutal plumes tend to rise, as it can be seen clearly in Fig. 7.

sec.title: Effect of Lewis number
sec.p: Lewis number is defined as the ratio of thermal diffusivity to mass diffusivity. Accordingly, an increase in the mass transfer rate is expected by an increase in the Lewis number.

Alterations in Lewis number result in changes in conductivity and the way fluid moves in the cavity. The effect of Lewis number is investigated in most double diffusive heat transfer studies. However, it should be noted that in each geometry and specific conditions, the parameters governing it lead to different results.

An increase in Lewis number results in a decrease in thickness of concentration boundary layer. Accordingly via confining the solutal driving force in thinner regime of velocity boundary layer, the intensity of induced solutal flow decreases, which is reported as the stream function as well as flow, temperature, and concentration lines.

In the present study, the Lewis number has been changed from 0.1 to 10 to determine its effect on fluid flow. The increase in Lewis number is accompanied by a decrease in the thickness of the mass boundary layer, and this decrease in thickness causes the forces produced by mass gradients to be located in thinner areas of the thermal boundary layer, which reduces the current induced by the mass gradients. It is reported based on the values of stream functions and contours of current, temperature, and concentration lines. These values are specified based on the unique geometry and specific conditions of the present study.

sec.title: Effect of Hartmann number
sec.p: Hartmann number is defined as the ratio of the electromagnetic force to the viscous force. As it was mentioned in the literature review section, in recent year the impact of magnetic field on fluid flow has gained attention. Applications include MEMS, microelectronics, geothermal, and more. The high importance has created a branch in fluid mechanics as magnetic nano fluid [27]. The innovative section of the present study in this part is the investigation of the impact of the magnetic field on various nanofluids to see which particle is influenced more from this field. Moreover, the effects of the magnetic field for the specific geometry of the problem is reported as the stream function as well as flow, temperature, and concentration lines.

Additionally, as Hartmann number is an increasing function of both magnetic field intensity and nanoparticle volume fraction, for a constant value of Hartmann number increase in volume fraction implies a reduction in the magnitude of the magnetic field. Figures 11 and 12 disclose that at constant Hartmann number, an increase in nanoparticle volume fraction dominates a decrease in magnetic intensity effect, and eventually heat and mass transfer rate increase.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Lattice Boltzmann method, known as (LMB) under laminar and steady-state conditions is employed. Patel model is applied to estimate the effective thermal conductivity of the nanofluid. The results of the numerical calculations are analyzed for different values of the volume fraction of nanoparticles, Rayleigh number, Lewis number, and Hartmann number to make it possible for studying the impact of mentioned parameters on heat and mass transfer on aforementioned nanofluids. The outcome of which are concisely stated as follows.

The effectiveness order of applied water based nanofluids were Ag, Cu, Al2O3 in terms of heat and mass transfer rate. Moreover, the average Nusselt and Sherwood numbers increased by increasing Rayleigh number, as it was expected. An increase in the volume fraction of the nanoparticles led to a greater average Nusselt number, particularly at high Rayleigh Numbers (where convection was the main heat transfer mechanism). An increase in Lewis number resulted in an increase in the value of the average Sherwood number. However, it did not affect the average Nusselt number significantly. By increasing Hartmann number for a constant value of nanoparticle volume fraction, the values of average Nusselt and Sherwood numbers decreased. The flow circulation in the cavity was damped by increasing magnetic field magnitude. The applied magnetic field has the greatest impact on Ag nanofluid in terms of reducing heat and mass transfer. After Ag, there are Cu and Al2O3.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
